name: Ted Cruz
content:
Kristen Clarke is one of the most radical nominees ever put forward for any position in the federal government, and today Democrats have voted to give her a top position at the Department of Justice. Let me be clear: Kristen Clarke is completely unfit to serve as Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Rights Division. Not only has she made her disgust for law enforcement clear by her repeated calls to defund the police, she has a history of not only excusing, but celebrating criminals who have murdered police officers. What are police officers across the country supposed to think about Democrats elevating someone to a senior position at the Department of Justice knowing that she has celebrated a brutal cop killer?

The Department of Justice has a long history of being apolitical, of exercising fidelity to the law, of not using the law as a partisan weapon to target enemies of whatever administration is in power. The Obama-Biden administration corrupted that practice, and now the Biden-Harris administration is continuing that pattern. I believe appointees to the Department of Justice should have a demonstrated record of fidelity to the law, impartiality, and the ability to defend the law. Kristen Clarke does not.

name: Nancy Pelosi
content:
Today, solemnly, marks one year since the murder of George Floyd. After seeing the heartbreaking video, millions of people around the world flooded the streets for days and weeks, marching to end the epidemic of police violence and to advance justice.

When the Floyd family asked if we would name our transformational police reform bill after George, my response was: ‚ÄúOnly if it is worthy.‚Äù Today, we are working hard to pass a bill worthy of George Floyd‚Äôs life and legacy.

The George Floyd #JusticeInPolicing Act, which has now passed twice in the House, is an opportunity to honor his life and all lives taken by the scourge of racial injustice. We remain hopeful that we will, in a bipartisan spirit, reach an agreement and enact this legislation.

name: Ralph Norman
content:
If there‚Äôs one photo that captures everything that‚Äôs honorable and compassionate and decent about our law enforcement officers, it‚Äôs this one.

Tyler Terry is a suspect in multiple murders here in South Carolina and Missouri. After opening fire on a Chester County Sheriff‚Äôs Deputy during a high-speed pursuit back on May 17th, a weeklong manhunt ensued. Over 300 officers from numerous local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies assisted in the search, which ultimately led to Terry‚Äôs capture and arrest yesterday. Neither Terry nor any officer was injured, thank God.

Enduring a 7-day manhunt for someone who had allegedly killed four people and recently tried to take the life of one of your fellow officers is stress that most of us probably cannot imagine. And yet when it was over, before the adrenaline had faded, Terry was cared for exactly the way we would expect, with a medical evaluation and fluids.

This is who our law enforcement officers are. And this is why they will ALWAYS have my support and respect.

There‚Äôs no shortage of people who believe our police should be ‚Äúdefunded‚Äù to varying degrees. In fact, there are more than a few Democrats in Congress who honestly believe this. But they have NO ANSWER when asked who would track down the next Tyler Terry, or who would answer the call next time they need help. People who think we need to defund our police are miserably wrong.

God bless every man and woman who walks the thin blue line. üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏üá∫üá∏

(Photo Credit: unconfirmed, but believed to be @ChesterSheriff.)

#supportthepolice #supportlawenforcement

name: Richard J. Durbin
content:
His name was George Floyd. He was a 46-year-old Black man. He was a father, a brother, a son, a friend. He died on the streets of Minneapolis with the knee of a police officer on his neck‚Äîan image that haunts me to this day. The injustice of his killing is undeniable. And so is the fact that systemic racism continues to plague America‚Äîincluding in far too many interactions between law enforcement and Black and Brown Americans.

This first anniversary serves as a sober reminder of why we must make real change and continue working to move our nation nearer to the goal of a system of justice that is applied equally to all.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
From Uzbekistan to Myanmar and Belarus, the past few weeks have been incredibly dangerous for journalists across the globe, as authoritarian regimes harass, intimidate, and silence those who seek to report the truth.

On Sunday, the Belarusian military regime hijacked a commercial flight to detain journalist Roman Protasevich. In Uzbekistan, blogger Otabek Sattoriy has been arrested under trumped-up charges related to his work as a journalist. And in Myanmar, American journalist Danny Fenster was detained at Yangon airport while trying to fly home. It is intolerable to target journalists, and every country has an obligation to ensure that press are protected.

An independent, free press is critical to democracy both at home and around the world, and as journalists increasingly come under assault, we must redouble our efforts to protect and promote the freedom of press. That‚Äôs why I previously introduced the Jamal Khashoggi Press Freedom Act to strengthen the United States‚Äô commitment to hold to account those governments and leaders who would target journalists for violence and persecution.

The next decade will be pivotal for the future of the free press, as global crises converge and test the resolve of our institutions and those who work to uphold them. America must always stand with journalists around the world who risk their freedom and their lives to expose corruption, provide platforms to independent and critical voices, and tell the difficult stories that must be told.

name: Tammy Duckworth
content:
On this day last year, we watched a fellow American be needlessly killed under the knee of a police officer who had taken an oath to protect and serve.

George Floyd‚Äôs family should have never dealt with this kind of pain‚Äîthis kind of loss‚Äîand George Floyd should be alive today.

We needed police reform long before George Floyd, Laquan McDonald, Breonna Taylor and so many more who have been senselessly killed. Their deaths have shown us that ‚Äúliberty and justice for all‚Äù is not yet a reality for Black Americans.

I know that I will never be able to fully comprehend the fear and trauma that Black Americans experience every day. But what I do know is that the burden of all this pain can‚Äôt fall on them alone.

We can't let another year go by without passing meaningful police reform. Until every Black American can breathe without a knee on their neck, no American should feel as if we‚Äôre truly able to take a breath.

No American worker should have to choose between their job and breastfeeding their baby. Ensuring that new mothers returning to the workplace have the option to continue breastfeeding is good for business and good for families. And in the wake of a pandemic that has disproportionately pushed women out of the workplace, my PUMP Act will help businesses improve retention of valuable employees, and empower parents to make their own choices, rather than being constrained by outdated workplace policies.

I‚Äôm glad to see this be voted out of the HELP Committee today and I will continue pushing for this bill until it becomes law.

MERKLEY.SENATE.GOV
Merkley, Murkowski, Booker Applaud Bipartisan Committee Passage of Legislation to Expand Breastfeeding Protections at Work | U.S. Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon

name: Jeff Merkley
content:
One year ago, George Floyd was murdered. Today, I‚Äôm thinking of his loved ones‚Äîhis daughter who has been without her father for a year, and all of the family, friends, and community who loved him. His life mattered. He should be alive today‚Äîas should so many other Black Americans killed by police brutality, negligence, and failure to serve our communities.

We must continue to root out racism in our public safety systems. We are way overdue for serious reforms to our public safety systems; and because Black lives matter, we must change these systems. Passing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is a small first step toward fixing the broken system that has failed so many.

We need to work toward justice. Justice is not simply holding one murderer accountable; it is a system free from racism. True justice is building a system in which Black lives are not stolen in the first place. I will always stand with you and work for you to fight for racial justice and to put an end to police brutality.

MEDIUM.COM
Our Work Continues

name: Mark Kelly
content:
Today marks one year since #GeorgeFloyd was murdered and taken from his family far too soon. My heart goes out to his loved ones, who must be feeling his loss especially hard today.

And though there was accountability in the verdict last month, the work continues towards a more just system that doesn‚Äôt discriminate against Black people because of the color of their skin.

As Americans continue to call for accountability in law enforcement and for reforms to address the systemic issues in our criminal justice system, we must all continue to do our part to speak out against racism wherever we find it.

My commitment to addressing our justice system still stands. I‚Äôm hopeful that we can find bipartisan agreement on federal reforms that will strengthen police accountability and oversight to make our communities safer and more just.

name: Dan Sullivan
content:
Yesterday, I attended the Oval Office signing of our Alaska Tourism Restoration Act. Whether with President Obama, President Trump, and now President Biden, when I have an opportunity to make the case directly to the President on an important issue for Alaska, I try to seize it. After the signing, I respectfully told President Biden that many of his administration's executive actions were viewed as harming Alaska‚Äôs economic opportunities and jobs. In particular, I highlighted the Biden administration's delay with regard to the Willow Project on the North Slope and handed the President a fact sheet on this very important energy project, not just for Alaska jobs and our working families, but for America's energy and national security interests.

The President listened to the details about why this NPR-A energy development project is so important and said that he and his team would get back to us soon on the status of the Willow Project. I appreciated his willingness to listen to the concerns of our fellow Alaskans on one of the most important energy projects in America right now.

name: Ted Lieu

A federal encryption standard is vital to our nation's security. As a computer science major, I can tell you that having 50 different mandatory state-level encryption standards is bad for security, consumers, innovation, and law enforcement.

I'm proud to join Representative Nancy Mace, along with Representatives DelBene and Eshoo, to reintroduce the bipartisan ENCRYPT Act, which will ensure a uniform, national policy for the interstate issue of encryption technology.

LIEU.HOUSE.GOV
REP LIEU INTRODUCES BIPARTISAN LEGISLATION TO STRENGTHEN U.S. ENCRYPTION LAWS

name: Christopher A. Coons
content:
A year ago today, George Floyd was murdered by a Minneapolis police officer in a horrific incident that galvanized the world. Months of protests and calls for change followed in Delaware, across our country, and around the world. A year later, while the police officer who killed George Floyd is now in jail, inequality in our society, challenges around policing, and violence in our streets continue.

As President Joe Biden said today after meeting with George Floyd's family, "We have to act. We face an inflection point."

He's right.

In the Senate, we are continuing to work towards a bill that will meaningfully reform policing and advance other efforts to improve racial equity and opportunity in housing, education, employment, access to capital, and health care. Today, we recommit ourselves to delivering real change for Delaware ‚Äì for communities that are struggling from Wilmington and Dover, to Ellendale and Seaford ‚Äì and for communities across the country.

We cannot miss this moment to make a difference.
text: year ago today george floyd murdered minneapolis police officer horrific incident galvanized world months protests calls change followed delaware across country around world year later police officer killed george floyd jail inequality society challenges around policing violence streets continueas president joe biden said today meeting george floyds family act face inflection pointhes rightin senate continuing work towards bill meaningfully reform policing advance efforts improve racial equity opportunity housing education employment access capital health care today recommit delivering real change delaware communities struggling wilmington dover ellendale seaford communities across countrywe cannot miss moment make difference

name: Neal P. Dunn
content:
Please join me in congratulating Kaitlyn McCarty of North Bay Haven Charter Academy, the winner of the 2021 Congressional Art Competition for Florida's Second Congressional District. Kaitlyn‚Äôs artwork, titled ‚ÄúThe Calm After The Storm,‚Äù is a watercolor portrait depicting a half-sunken sailboat off the coast of Panama City, left behind after the devastation of Hurricane Michael.

I would also like to congratulate Anna Barber of Marianna High School, who was awarded second place for her painting titled ‚ÄúStunning. Refreshing‚Ä¶Essential.‚Äù Tied for 3rd place was Jake Wooley of Suwannee High School with his sketch titled ‚ÄúQuiet Reverie‚Äù and Elizabeth Baggett of Marianna High School with her piece titled ‚ÄúThe Joseph W. Russ House.‚Äù

We had an exceptional selection of entries from young artists throughout Florida‚Äôs Second Congressional District this year. As many know, Hurricane Michael caused a great deal of devastation throughout our district. Kaitlyn‚Äôs painting not only reflects the destruction but also gives a sense of hope. This piece is a reminder to all of us that we can overcome whatever disaster comes our way, and that‚Äôs the perfect message following this pandemic. I look forward to seeing Kaitlyn‚Äôs artwork hanging in the Capitol for visitors from across the country to see.

Thank you to all our participants for your inspiring contributions, and to our judges for helping us choose the winners!

name: Pramila Jayapal

Today marks a year since George Floyd was murdered. My heart is with his family ‚Äî and all Black and Brown families who have had a loved one taken from them by the police. George Floyd's life mattered. Let's honor it with action ‚Äî organizing to end police brutality.

A first transformative step is finally passing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, and sending it to the President's desk. Then, we must continue the urgent work in communities all across America to end racism, anti-Blackness, and police brutality. We owe it to his memory.

name: Benjamin L. Cardin
content:
I recently joined Senator Rob Portman (R-Ohio) to introduce the Retirement Security & Savings Act (S. 1770), a broad set of reforms designed to strengthen Americans‚Äô retirement security.

The bill addresses four major opportunities in the existing retirement system:

(1) allowing people who have saved too little to set more aside for their retirement;
(2) helping small businesses offer 401(k)s and other retirement plans;
(3) expanding access to retirement savings plans, including for low-income Americans without coverage; and
(4) providing more certainty and flexibility during Americans‚Äô retirement years.

The measure includes more than 50 provisions to accomplish these objectives.

Americans need to save more so they can retire with the dignity and stability the deserve. It‚Äôs an ongoing struggle, especially during the pandemic when millions of Americans were without work for months or longer and small businesses struggled to make ends meet. We have an opportunity to make this process simpler and more beneficial to families and workers. There is strong bipartisan momentum to strengthen our retirement system and ensure Americans can achieve post-work financial stability.

PIONLINE.COM
Senators reintroduce bipartisan retirement security package
text: recently joined senator rob portman rohio introduce retirement security savings act broad set reforms designed strengthen americans retirement securitythe bill addresses four major opportunities existing retirement system1 allowing people saved little set aside retirement2 helping small businesses offer 401ks retirement plans3 expanding access retirement savings plans including lowincome americans without coverage and4 providing certainty flexibility americans retirement yearsthe measure includes provisions accomplish objectivesamericans need save retire dignity stability deserve ongoing struggle especially pandemic millions americans without work months longer small businesses struggled make ends meet opportunity make process simpler beneficial families workers strong bipartisan momentum strengthen retirement system ensure americans achieve postwork financial stabilitypionlinecomsenators reintroduce bipartisan retirement security package

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
Oklahomans are well aware of the need to invest in bridges. Our state used to be one of the worst states for having a high number of structurally deficient bridges, but because of my work in SAFETEA-LU, MAP-21 and the FAST Act, Oklahoma received the federal resources needed to make bridge repairs and replacement a priority. Today, we are ninth in the nation for having the fewest number of structurally deficient highway system bridges. Now, we cannot rest on our past success, we need to continue to make improving our nation‚Äôs infrastructure a priority. That‚Äôs why I am glad to re-introduce the Bridge Investment Act alongside Sen. Brown and I will work to ensure its inclusion in the bipartisan Surface Transportation Reauthorization Act of 2021.

INHOFE.SENATE.GOV
U.S. Senator for Oklahoma

name: Ken Buck
content:
I‚Äôm pleased that D.C. Attorney General Karl Racine has taken legal action to hold Amazon accountable for its egregious anticompetitive behavior.

Amazon has monopolized the e-commerce marketplace by imposing anti-competitive contract provisions on third-party sellers ‚Äî stifling innovation, targeting small businesses, and robbing consumers of choice.

name: John P. Sarbanes
content:
Today marks the one-year anniversary of the brutal killing of George Floyd by police in Minnesota.

Last month‚Äôs verdict in the Chauvin trial finally delivered some accountability for this heinous crime. But we must keep up the fight for justice and civil rights and we must ensure that Black and Brown lives are valued and respected by law enforcement officers across the country.

In that important effort, I joined my colleagues earlier this year to pass the George Floyd #JusticeInPolicing Act, which would transform policing across the country. The Senate must immediately take up the bill, pass it and send it to President Biden‚Äôs desk.

name: Richard Hudson
content:
Today marks the one year anniversary of the murder of George Floyd, who was born in our community. Two things I know ‚Äì first, most police officers are good police officers. They risk their lives every day to protect us and should be supported. Second, there are legitimate concerns, particularly in the African American community, that must be recognized. We all have a responsibility to work for justice. I‚Äôve been focused on bipartisan reform that does both.

As part of that work, I‚Äôve written an amendment to the George Floyd Justice and Policing Act to ensure accountability and transparency are not hindered by collective bargaining agreements by unions that protect bad officers with a pattern of misconduct. I am hopeful our ongoing negotiations bear fruit because there is so much we agree on like ending chokeholds, training for officers to intervene when they observe fellow officers using excessive force, reporting requirements on ‚Äúno-knock‚Äù warrants and the use of force that causes death or serious injury, and expanding body-worn cameras.

As I said when I was asked to speak at the memorial service for George Floyd last year, there is work to be done, but we can pass common sense solutions by working together.
text: today marks one year anniversary murder george floyd born community two things know first police officers good police officers risk lives every day protect us supported second legitimate concerns particularly african american community must recognized responsibility work justice ive focused bipartisan reform bothas part work ive written amendment george floyd justice policing act ensure accountability transparency hindered collective bargaining agreements unions protect bad officers pattern misconduct hopeful ongoing negotiations bear fruit much agree like ending chokeholds training officers intervene observe fellow officers using excessive force reporting requirements noknock warrants use force causes death serious injury expanding bodyworn camerasas said asked speak memorial service george floyd last year work done pass common sense solutions working together

name: Adam Smith
content:
George Floyd‚Äôs murder was one year ago today, and my thoughts are with his family and loved ones.

Our nation is still suffering from the enduring impacts of systemic racism, and we must work to fundamentally change policing ‚Äì there must be accountability and transparency.

We saw the judicial system work to hold Derek Chauvin accountable for the murder of George Floyd by convicting him on all three criminal charges, but it does not change the fact that his life was brutally cut short and he should still be alive today.

We owe it to him and countless others to continue to combat systemic racism, work to eliminate police brutality, and ensure police are held accountable when they fail to protect the communities they serve.

We must get the George Floyd #JusticeinPolicingAct to the president's desk.

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
Today, the Armed Services Committee heard from three key nominees for the Department of Defense: Frank Kendall to be Secretary of the Air Force, Heidi Shyu to be Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, and Susanna Blume to be director of Cost Assessment and Program Evaluation.

I took the opportunity to ask them their views on the critical defense capabilities we need to deter our adversaries ‚Äì specifically, the F-35 fifth-generation fighter and emerging technologies like hypersonic weapons, artificial intelligence, and microelectronics.

I was glad to hear these nominees share my views on the importance of making sure we have these capabilities by funding them adequately. I visited McAlester over the weekend, and they also were excited about her nomination!

name: Tom Emmer
content:
Every American deserves due process protections and a fair trial. For many low-income individuals who struggle to afford a lawyer, that can seem out of reach. Civil legal aid is critical to bridging this gap, serving those affected by addiction, natural disasters, domestic violence, families with children, homeowners and renters, the disabled, the elderly, veterans, and many more. I recently sent a letter in support of continued funding of the Legal Services Corporation, a program that provides legal aid services for 1.8 million Americans. Read more here: https://emmer.house.gov/press-releases?id=FD1795D7-0A8E-44B6-A397-A04B58716D59

EMMER.HOUSE.GOV
Emmer Supports Funding for Legal Aid Services

name: Ruben Gallego
content:
On the one year anniversary of the murders of George Floyd and Dion Johnson, my thoughts are with their families and loved ones, and with the families and loved ones of too many other Black Americans whose lives have been stolen.

The nationwide protests last summer sparked a renewed national movement to combat police brutality and dismantle systemic racism ‚Äì but much work remains to be done. We must tackle racial injustice and police abuse head-on, and we must fight for the Senate to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act that passed the House of Representatives earlier this year. While I‚Äôm encouraged by the recent guilty verdict in Derek Chauvin‚Äôs trial for the murder of George Floyd, we must make sure that true accountability is the rule, and not the rare exception.

Signing major reforms into law and transforming the culture of law enforcement in America is a matter of life and death, especially for Black and Brown communities. We cannot stop fighting until we achieve true racial justice in our country.
text: one year anniversary murders george floyd dion johnson thoughts families loved ones families loved ones many black americans whose lives stolenthe nationwide protests last summer sparked renewed national movement combat police brutality dismantle systemic racism much work remains done must tackle racial injustice police abuse headon must fight senate pass george floyd justice policing act passed house representatives earlier year im encouraged recent guilty verdict derek chauvins trial murder george floyd must make sure true accountability rule rare exceptionsigning major reforms law transforming culture law enforcement america matter life death especially black brown communities cannot stop fighting achieve true racial justice country

name: Kirsten E. Gillibrand
content:
Once again, I asked for unanimous consent for a floor vote on the Military Justice Improvement and Increasing Prevention Act.

Once again, the motion was objected to.

Our service members deserve better. We now have 64 bipartisan cosponsors. It's time to pass this bill and deliver justice.

In 2014, I asked for a vote on this bill. It had 55 votes ‚Äì but it was filibustered.

In 2015, I asked for a vote. It earned majority support again, but was filibustered.

I asked for a vote in 2016, and 2017, and 2018, and 2019, and 2020. And I was denied every time.

We now have a filibuster-proof, bipartisan majority of senators who support this legislation and want to enact this reform. But this vote is being denied AGAIN.

On behalf of the service members who do so much for our country ‚Äî put the Military Justice Improvement and Increasing Prevention Act up for a vote.

America‚Äôs economy will continue to import workers and goods until there is sufficient labor force participation to sustain growth. name: Lisa Murkowski
content:
Today the Senate HELP Committee advanced legislation I‚Äôm leading to improve maternal health, address infant mortality, and support nursing mothers in the workplace. Moms living in rural areas are more likely to experience maternal mortality and morbidity than those living in urban areas. The Rural MOMS Act will help ensure that new and expecting moms living in rural communities receive the care they need. And the PUMP Act provides salaried employees in traditional office environments with adequate break time and a private place to pump breastmilk. For moms who choose to nurse, they need the adequate time and the space to do so in the workplace. I‚Äôm proud to advance legislation to help keep Alaska‚Äôs mothers and babies healthy and thriving.

Read more here: https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/murkowskis-maternal-health-bills-advance-from-committee
text: today senate help committee advanced legislation im leading improve maternal health address infant mortality support nursing mothers workplace moms living rural areas likely experience maternal mortality morbidity living urban areas rural moms act help ensure new expecting moms living rural communities receive care need pump act provides salaried employees traditional office environments adequate break time private place pump breastmilk moms choose nurse need adequate time space workplace im proud advance legislation help keep alaskas mothers babies healthy thrivingread

name: Brendan F. Boyle
content:
Good news--The City of Philadelphia just launched a Homebound Vaccination referral program for people who are normally unable to leave their home without help, or those unable to leave home due to disability, or access issues.

This program helps people who are homebound and their families to schedule in-home vaccination services through different vaccine providers. As part of this program, Personal Care Attendants, family, and any other caregivers or residents of the household are ALSO eligible to be vaccinated during the same visit.

If you are interested in setting up a vaccine appointment for yourself or a person who is homebound, call 215-685-5488 (dial 711 for TRS/TTY assistance) or click the link below and just fill out the form. Once you are registered, you will be contacted to schedule an in-home vaccination visit.

https://redcap.phila.gov/surveys/?s=WCAXTJ8H8P

REDCAP.PHILA.GOV
COVID Vaccine Needs for Homebound Persons

name: House Committee on Veterans' Affairs GOP
content:
Veterans who were exposed to toxins need our help.

It's time for VA to meet this moment and come to the negotiating table.

"We don't want a bill that ends up being so expensive it falls under its own weight," RM Rep. Mike Bost said.

That's why Ranking Member Bost recently sent a letter to Secretary McDonough asking for the Administrations views and cost estimates ASAP on each of the 15 proposals the Committee considered earlier this month.

Thousands of veterans are suffering and we can't drag our feet.

name: Stacey E. Plaskett
content:
Congressional Black Caucus on the One Year Commemoration of the Murder of George Floyd

CBC Members offer words of reflection and action after the one year commemoration of the murder of George Floyd at the hands of Convicted Law Enforcement Officer Derek Chauvin

WASHINGTON, D.C. ‚Äî Today, Tuesday, May 25, 2021, marks one year since the horrific murder of George Floyd by former police officer Derek Chauvin. Chauvin was found guilty of all three charges brought against him on April 20, 2021. Mr. Floyd‚Äôs murder was filmed on a camera phone and shared all over the world. Individuals nationwide organized to march, protest, and kneel in honor of George Floyd.

The Congressional Black Caucus (CBC), led by Chair Joyce Beatty, has been instrumental in advocating for change to prevent police brutality and killings of unarmed Black people. In response to George Floyd‚Äôs murder and in honor of the many others who have died due to police brutality, Congresswoman Karen Bass, in partnership with other Members of the Congressional Black Caucus, introduced The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is a bold, comprehensive bill focused on addressing police misconduct and creating systemic changes in policing. This comprehensive law enforcement reform bill seeks to improve police accountability, change the culture of law enforcement, and build trust between law enforcement, communities of color, and the American people.

Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett (VI-00) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúBeing the mother of 4 young Black men AND a member of Congress, I know that we must examine the social disparities that disproportionately affect Black men and boys in America. In 2019, Black people made up 24 percent of the police killings in the United States. A year later, let us keep in our prayers the family of George Floyd and all the families that are living through the tragedy of having lost someone at the hands of law enforcement - individuals who are supposed to serve and protect. The next step is justice for the countless other victims. Here in Washington, we must continue to work in order to reform the criminal justice system by passing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, and we must work toward a more just and perfect union. BLACK LIVES MATTER!!!!!‚Äù

Congressional Black Caucus Chair Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúExactly one year ago, the world watched in horror as George Floyd was brutally murdered. While the former police officer responsible for his death has been convicted, that is not always the case. So, I will continue to say the names and fight for all those who have died or been injured senselessly by law enforcement. Breonna Taylor, Daunte Wright, Adam Toledo, Andre Hill, Casey Goodson, Jr., Ma‚ÄôKhia Bryant, Tamir Rice, and George Floyd should be alive. Unfortunately, nothing will ever bring them back or undo the unimaginable heartache and loss their family, friends, and our communities have had to endure, but we can turn agony into action. The American people are demanding change, transparency, accountability, and equal justice. That is why I am calling on the Senate to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act immediately.‚Äù

Congressional Black Caucus First Vice-Chair Congressman Steven Horsford (NV-04) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúOne year ago, the horrific murder of George Floyd exposed the world to the trauma and fear that Black families experience every day. As a Black man raising Black children, I know that George Floyd‚Äôs death was not just about one officer or one department ‚Äî it was the result of a broken system that too often views innocent Black men and women as threats. While the guilty verdict in Derek Chauvin‚Äôs trial gave us a moment of relief, true justice would have kept George Floyd alive and with his family today. As we mourn George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and the hundreds of lives lost to law enforcement over the last year, we must act. The road to reform begins with passing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, but we need systemic change to root out bias and build a safer world for Black people and all Americans.‚Äù

Congressional Black Caucus Second Vice-Chair Congressman Brenda Lawrence (MI-14) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd should still be alive today. In the year following his murder, people all over the United States‚Äîand around the world‚Äîraised their voices for change. For George and the countless others who have lost their lives to police brutality, we need to get the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act passed in the Senate and signed into law. This is about accountability, transparency, and justice. On the anniversary of his murder, I‚Äôm sending strength and love to George‚Äôs family.‚Äù

Majority Whip James E. Clyburn (SC-06) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúThe lynching of George Floyd was a moment in history that ignited an historic movement that hopefully will help redefine policing in our nation. And hopefully the conviction of Derick Chauvin for perpetrating this inhumane act will help restore humanity and accountability in the culture of policing. My thoughts and prayers are with the Floyd family today and always for the profound loss they have suffered.‚Äù

Chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, Congressman Hakeem Jeffries (NY-08) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúA year ago today, the murder of George Floyd made clear the challenge that our nation has with police violence, police brutality, and the police abuse of force. Over the past 12 months, people of goodwill throughout America spoke up, stood up, and showed up to demand justice. House Democrats passed the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act to bring accountability and transparency to police forces, and now the Senate must step up and also pass this crucial legislation. Today, as we remember George Floyd, we must also continue to recognize those seeking change and work together to continue our march toward a more perfect union.‚Äù

Chairwoman of the House Committee on Financial Services, Congresswoman Maxine Waters (CA-43) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúToday marks 1 year since George Floyd was murdered. We must always remember the 9+ minutes that Chauvin kneeled on his neck and we must be committed to holding police accountable. George Floyd & others who have met similar fates must not have died in vain. The struggle continues.‚Äù

Congressman Hank Johnson (GA-04) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúWhile George Floyd‚Äôs murderer is behind bars preparing to be sentenced, so much more work needs to be done to hold police accountable and stop the killing of unarmed Black people in America. A good place to start would be for the Senate to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. Many states and law enforcement agencies across the country have begun to reform their laws and use-of-force practices, but in just the last year, there have been hundreds of officer-involved deaths in the U.S. We still need federal legislation to help demilitarize police, ban chokeholds nationwide and bring more accountability and justice to our communities.‚Äù

Congresswoman Frederica S. Wilson (FL-24) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúA lot has changed since May 25, 2020. Millions of people of all races and ethnicities poured out into the streets for weeks in the midst of a pandemic to protest Chauvin‚Äôs cold-blooded actions. Confederate monuments have been removed. Diversifying the workplace has become less of a politically correct theory and more of an action taking place in businesses and corporations across the United States. Greater investments are being made in black businesses, communities, and arts, and several states have passed police reform legislation.

But the more things change, the more they stay the same. Black Americans are three times as likely to be killed by the police than whites. And, since Floyd‚Äôs murder, several other unarmed black men have been slain by police officers. Their families are still crying for justice. As we near the end of the pandemic and return to more normal lives, I pray that the millions of people who rallied for justice throughout this past year will not stop fighting for it. I know I won‚Äôt.‚Äù

Congresswoman Cori Bush (MO-01) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúWe must acknowledge that the knee on George Floyd‚Äôs neck was just one injustice in a series of compounding systems of racism and structural inequity that he experienced in his life. A descendant of enslaved people, George Floyd was born with generational trauma in his DNA and denied the generational wealth that belonged to his family. He survived the vicious cycle of our racist incarceration system and opioid crisis. He suffered through COVID-19 like so many Black and brown people across our communities.

Despite the adversity that George Floyd endured, he was full of life and love for his family, friends, and loved ones. It was in honor of his life that millions took to the streets in struggle for a world where George Floyd would never have been taken from us. We honor his life, legacy, and name by doing the work of achieving justice each and every day.‚Äù

Congresswoman Alma Adams (NC-12) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd and all of the people who we have lost to police violence are not martyrs or symbols or hashtags so much as they were parents, siblings, children, and members of their community. While we march in the streets after a shooting, a family is sitting in a funeral home, grieving. A pastor is finding a new singer for Sunday morning. A hospital is trying to find someone to cover shifts in the ER. Police killings are not only acts of violence against an individual; they‚Äôre an act of violence against a community, and that is why communities across the country have taken a stand over the past year.‚Äù

We must continue to take action by speaking up, by investing in our neighborhoods and families, and by passing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act so that these killings, these attacks on our communities, become a thing of the past. That is how we will best approach justice in an unjust world,‚Äù

Congresswoman Terri Sewell (AL-07) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd should be alive today, and while his murderer was held accountable, the same cannot be said for countless Black Americans who continue to be killed at the hands of those whose job it is to serve and protect. On the one-year anniversary of George Floyd‚Äôs murder, we must recommit ourselves to the fight for true justice and see to it that the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is signed into law. It is impossible to change history without demanding the change we want to see.‚Äù

Congressman Anthony G. Brown (MD-04) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd should still be alive. While his murderer was held accountable, we must do more to ensure true justice in our country. Communities of color have continued to grapple with all too familiar stories of police violence. Each new killing reopening an all too familiar cycle of pain, anger, and calls for reform. Congress has a duty to pass meaningful police accountability legislation.

We must change the culture of policing in our country to ensure officers act as guardians of our communities rather than a militarized force. Maryland is already leading and taking long-overdue steps to limit the use of force, restrict no-knock warrants and ensure police officers are accountable to the communities they serve. It‚Äôs time to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act to bring these reforms nationwide.‚Äù

Congresswoman Lisa Blunt Rochester (D-Del.) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúWe cannot rest until we pass the Justice in Policing Act in George Floyd‚Äôs name. As the mother of a Black son, listening to George Floyd cry out for his mother will haunt me forever. As we mark one year since his death, let us never forget the humanity for which we fight.‚Äù

‚ÄúLet us never forget that George‚Äôs life mattered - and that the lives of countless others whose names we know and don‚Äôt know matter too. But as we mark one year since his passing, we can also recognize the truth in the words of his daughter, Gianna - George Floyd changed the world. May we continue to change it for the better in his memory.‚Äù

Congressman Bobby L. Rush (IL-01) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúGeorge Floyd‚Äôs gruesome murder at the hands ‚Äî or rather, the knee ‚Äî of a heartless police officer shocked our nation‚Äôs conscience and sparked a historic wave of activism in righteous defense of Black lives, reminiscent of the way that Emmett Till‚Äôs lynching sent shockwaves through the country and galvanized a generation of civil rights leaders more than half a century ago,‚Äù Rush said. ‚ÄúOn this solemn anniversary, we mourn the death of George Floyd and countless other Black men killed at the hands of police, and we look forward, with hope and determination, to passing comprehensive legislation that will reform the broken institution of policing in this nation.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe have to address the ruthless violence of the police profession. Our police forces must be highly professional, highly educated, highly trained, and highly paid personnel who adhere to the highest standards of public safety and public protection. Only the best of us should be able to carry out arrests and imprison and enforce the laws of our nation ‚Äî only the best, not the worst. We still have a long way to go to ensure that every American has a guaranteed right to equal justice under the law. As we mark this solemn anniversary in the wake of Derek Chauvin‚Äôs guilty verdict, we must remember that police accountability is not synonymous with justice.‚Äù

Congresswoman Lucy McBath (GA-06) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúThere is no action that can be taken, nor decision that can be made that would bring George Floyd back to his family. We must continue to look forward toward peace and progress, and we must work harder to pass legislation to ensure justice shines bright for every single American.‚Äù

Congresswoman Yvette D. Clarke (NY-09) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúOur system of law enforcement must be guided by a humane and equitable approach to justice. This happens through a comprehensive approach to holding police accountable. Through decisive changes to law enforcement culture, thorough empowering our communities, and most importantly through addressing systemic racism and bias. It is time to make the change; no more lives should be lost to chokeholds and no-knock warrants ‚Äî which took the lives of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and Eric Garner. No more lives should be lost during routine traffic stops ‚Äî which took the lives of Duante Wright, Rayshard Brooks, and Philando Castile. It is time to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, full stop. We honor your memory with action, dear brother George Floyd. No more lives should be lost due to police violence.‚Äù

Congressman Kweisi Mfume (MD-07) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúFor too long, the relationships between some communities and some law enforcement officers sworn to protect them have been strained and often spoiled. Defenseless men and women have too often been unjustifiably beaten and murdered at the hands of some police officers. The George Floyd murder is one example,‚Äù said Congressman Kweisi Mfume. ‚ÄúAs members of Congress, we must continue to advance reforms of our criminal justice system and pass police accountability legislation, once and for all.‚Äù

Congresswoman Marilyn Strickland (WA-10) offered the following quote: ‚ÄúMy heart goes out to George Floyd‚Äôs family on this solemn day as we mourn his loss and honor him with action. While we cannot bring George Floyd back, we must do everything in our power to reform how law enforcement engages with all communities, especially communities of color. The U.S. Senate cannot wait another day. It's time to take action on police reform to improve public safety for all people.‚Äù

The landmark legislation has already passed in the House, and we will continue using ‚ÄúOur Power [and] Our Message‚Äù to urge the Senate to take up the Act and get it to the President‚Äôs desk to be signed into law.

# # #

name: Bobby L. Rush
content:
George Floyd‚Äôs gruesome murder at the hands ‚Äî or rather, the knee ‚Äî of a heartless police officer shocked our nation‚Äôs conscience and sparked a historic wave of activism in righteous defense of Black lives, reminiscent of the way that Emmett Till‚Äôs lynching sent shockwaves through the country and galvanized a generation of civil rights leaders more than half a century ago.

On this solemn anniversary, we mourn the death of George Floyd and countless other Black men killed at the hands of police, and we look forward, with hope and determination, to passing comprehensive legislation that will reform the broken institution of policing in this nation.

Rush Statement Marking One Year Since George Floyd's Murder

name: Bobby L. Rush
content:
TODAY: My virtual housing resource fair continues with a workshop on housing and rental assistance from 4-5:30 PM CT this afternoon.

Zoom link: https://ushr.zoomgov.com/s/1606550423
No password is required.

We will be joined by representatives from local housing agencies including Neighborhood Housing Services of Chicago, AGORA Community Services, South Suburban Housing Center, the Dearborn Real Estate Board, and the City of Chicago Department of Housing to discuss COVID-19 housing relief options. Attendees will have the opportunity to ask questions and receive individual assistance and guidance. The Zoom event will also be streamed live right here on Facebook.

More information about this week's programming and the link to watch last night's event can be found on my website at Rush.House.Gov/HousingFair.

USHR.ZOOMGOV.COM
Video Conferencing, Web Conferencing, Online Meetings, Screen Sharing - Zoom
